text: What's up outliers bit of a day out there time for your weekly game stop update. Now there was not a game stop stream this past weekend because your boy was getting over some food poisoning from those haters over at Chipotle, but we're feeling better now and ready to get back caught up with everything that's going on. And there was some interesting news that broke today from Ryan Cohen. I think it broke yesterday. We'll talk about that a little bit later. I thought that we would start with just analyzing where we're at now today with the company and how things look because the broad market right now is going through a bit of a contraction. So some of the movement that we're seeing in game stop recently is unique to game stop, meaning the company itself and the overall movement of shares for the company itself. Then also some of this is literally broader across the entire market because if we take a look at let's say the SP 500 for example, you can see the SP 500 is down for consecutive days. It's shedding. So this is actually the the broader market closing in not quite there yet, but closing in on a correction. About a third of the way they're defining it as a 10 pullback from term highs. So it's moving in that direction, but I think it still has a way to go from the broader market. So some of this overall

text: might do is when I roll these short puts, I might size these down by one contract. By sizing this down by one contract, I unlock another hundred shares that I have access to to do whatever I want. And in this case, what I would want is as GameStop starts to consolidate and show strength, slowly start nibbling on some shares to build up this position. Now this is the downside. Essentially of managing a smaller position. Like if I was managing, you can see the other coverage strangle that I typically trade. They're larger positions because you need a decent bit of capital in order to employ the idea in its largest and purest form. But even with a really small allocation of 25,000, it's still completely viable. It just means we have to be a little more cautious with the silver bullets that we use and the silver bullets, meaning the remaining money. So the scenario here actually is pretty, pretty simple, to be honest. We're not using a bunch of the total amount allocated to it in the shares. We're literally using only 7,000 of this total 25. text: is tied to these short puts, which is exactly what I want. I want it as a satellite position. Because right now, this would be something I just continue to hold. There's nothing I need to do with this. The basis is fine. It's a little high, but it's okay, and it'll absolutely come down as I slowly start to scale in with more shares. So that's all there is to be done here. It's a little bit of taking a tactical pause, letting things move as they do. One of the cool things about trading the coverage strangle is even though this kind of stuff is going on, we still have profits built from prior short options that we've sold and taken in. So we have 692 and puts 353 in short calls. None of this is right home about, but if you think about it, it's about a thousand bucks on something that that's realized profit. And in the time span that I started trading this for you all, it's up about 0.45. So it's not a bad return. That's realized PNL. That's not including what's up here, the extra 142. And this will probably come in at a loss because I'm going to have to roll it. But the point is by trading these options around it, even though it's not doing what we would like it to do, we can still make some money. So that's the game plan is now. If you have any questions,
